trial_identification.studytitle: Randomised controlled trial (RCT) of biofeedback in patients with faecal incontinence
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised clinical study was designed to compare two exercise regimen and determine the effect of an information session on the subjective rating of the symptoms of faecal incontinence and quality of life

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Other diseases of the mouth, teeth, oesophagus, digestive system including liver and colon

interventions.interventions: A regimen of prescribed rapid exercises (up to 40, 1 second squeezes) and sustained (up to 40, 10 second squeeze) per day for 5 weeks (Session 3, Week 3 to Session 5, Week 8). Session 1 included severity, quality of life, and physiological (manometry) assessment, medical/surgical history and review of bowel chart/food diary. Session 2 included re-assessment of severity and quality of life plus relaxation breathing training.
interventions.comparator: Standard exercise regime which used only sustained exercises e.g. (up to 40, 10 second squeeze) per day for 5 weeks (Session 3, Week 3 to Session 5, Week 8) Session 1 included severity, quality of life, and physiological (manometry) assessment, medical/surgical history and review of bowel chart/food diary. Session 2 included re-assessment of severity and quality of life plus relaxation breathing training.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: Participants surveyed after consenting to participate in session 1 and after completing therapy 7 weeks/49 days later at the end of session 5.

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Participants surveyed after consenting to participate in session 1 and after completing therapy 7 weeks/49 days later at the end of session 5.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Faecal incontinence; show some increase in anal sphincter pressure during voluntary squeeze; are able to perceive a distended rectal balloon at a threshold of <150cc; are capable of understanding and cooperating; are willing to participate and consent.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Children (under 18); patients with: gastrointestinal stoma, self reported pregnancy, terminal illness, rectal prolapses, mental illness (by medication type)
